snippet.textDisplay: The idea is to stay at home and practice social distancing so slow the spread of COVID 19 so less people are infected at once. This gives doctors a chance to assist patients with severe cases to get the medical treatment they need without the fear of being overwhelmed and running out of resources (beds, ventilators, masks, etc).
snippet.textOriginal: The idea is to stay at home and practice social distancing so slow the spread of COVID 19 so less people are infected at once. snippet.textDisplay: Most of this seems common sense to me but I did take a lot of math in college. The biggest problem with this presentation and in general with how problems are typically solved is you have expert epidemiologists who know all this stuff but they are either unable or unwilling to speak to other specialists that work in economics and politics to come up with an optimized solution that not only prevents a lot of deaths from the virus but also comes with an exit plan. I suspect many people will also likely die in the recession that will likely follow all this as well..

snippet.textDisplay: 5:21 "But luckily, we can make it look like this instead, if we change how our S curve looks. And how we do that is by lowering the constant we multiply by from day to day in our exponential growth." You can't lower a constant. It will have to be a variable.
snippet.textOriginal: 5:21 "But luckily, we can make it look like this instead, if we change how our S curve looks. And how we do that is *by lowering the constant* we multiply by from day to day in our exponential growth." You can't lower a constant. It will have to be a variable.

snippet.textDisplay: We are such a reactionary species. We aren’t even discussing the long term ramifications of an indefinite economic shutdown. This shutdown will affect every age group including health and sick. Crime will increase because people need to eat. Stress will cause more illness. People won’t be able to afford medical treatment. People will be homeless. It’s completely unreasonable to demand perfectly healthy people to put themselves at risk of financial ruin to save a small, old, and ill sector of society.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for that well thought out explanation. I would also like to add that our health care system has always been fragile and easily overwhelmed. There were never enough hospitals, doctors and nurses even during none pandemic times. The system is flawed and needs major overhaul. The indefinite quarantine that we are currently experiencing is not a sustainable model. Millions will lose jobs and get seriously ill because income is directly related to health. Again causing more strain to the system. This time, people won’t even be able to afford to go to the hospital. There will be another pandemic in our lifetime and we need a better solution.
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you for that well thought out explanation. I would also like to add that our health care system has always been fragile and easily overwhelmed. snippet.textDisplay:
I want to ask something about flattening the curve, cause it's in my mind these days:
1. why can we provide more hospital beds and respirators during pandemic, cause I think it would go on for about 4-6 months, surely health industry would try to do it, Covid19 is not like Ebola right, incubation period is about 12-14 days, sick period about 5-8 days and then another 10-12 days for recovery period, so one person cycle is about 4-6 weeks in total
2. how to increase total number of people in R bucket (recover from pandemic)?! I know people always said virus is new, there's still no vaccine or definite cure for it, however desperate times need desperate measures, and we're really need it now more than ever. I read that Vietnam has a 100 percent recovery rate, what can we learn from that is actually essential to fulfill R bucket, rather than basically just saying to people: stay at home until this is over, because if Covid19 is behaving like seasonal flu, or maybe even all year flu, not many countries nor cities would be able to withstand a year lockdown
I really hope I get some answers about it, thanks

snippet.textDisplay:
This virus has my name on it (no, I am not "Mr Covid"). I am old, diabetic, male asthmatic and have no spleen to help produce antibodies. I am in strict isolation currently, but I depend on my family to stay healthy too.
With two brothers who are doctors, one a nurse in a care home and another who is a head teacher, they are all doing a fantastic job keeping this virus at bay. Logically, if we all isolate for two or three weeks the virus dies out.
Best wishes to all, stay healthy.
NOW WASH YOUR HANDS (and sterilize your phone!)
snippet.textOriginal:
This virus has my name on it (no, I am not "Mr Covid"). I am old, diabetic, male asthmatic and have no spleen to help produce antibodies.  I am in strict isolation currently, but I depend on my family to stay healthy too.

Best wishes to all, stay healthy. 
NOW WASH YOUR HANDS (and sterilize your phone!)

snippet.textDisplay:
Similar concept as the penny versus a million dollars question. Hear's the question; which would you choose, to receive a million dollars all at once on the first day of the month or start with a penny a day and the amount doubling each consecutive day until the month ended? The month in question has 30 days.
So on the first of the month you have a penny. On day 2 you have 2 cents. Day three you have 4 cents and on day four you have 8 cents. Continue to double the amount for each day and you will be surprised at what you have after day 30.
snippet.textOriginal:

So on the first of the month you have a penny. On day 2 you have 2 cents. Day three you have 4 cents and on day four you have 8 cents. Continue to double the amount for each day and you will be surprised at what you have after day 30.

Thats all good to quarantine and wait for the virus to die off, but what people are not understanding is the virus will not die off because it will still be carried by the animals from which it came / evolved. snippet.textDisplay: There is a key fallacy with the argument and that is the number and effacacy of the testing. Naturally more tests will produce more positives. South Korea fir example has conducted over 250K tests while the US just reached 200K and Japan is at 15K with a resulting flattened curve.

snippet.textDisplay:
The problem is...There is no perfect test for pretty much any infectious disease I can think of,” Dr. Jeanne Marrazzo, director of the infectious disease.

Tests for other infectious diseases can also fail to detect some cases. A panel of tests used to screen for respiratory viruses when pneumonia is suspected can give negative results even if a patient is infected, Dr. Marrazzo said. So can rapid tests for flu and strep throat. Blood tests for H.I.V. can miss the diagnosis in people who were recently infected.
snippet.textOriginal:
The problem is...There is no perfect test for pretty much any infectious disease I can think of,” Dr. Jeanne Marrazzo, director of the infectious disease.

So can rapid tests for flu and strep throat. Blood tests for H.I.V. can miss the diagnosis in people who were recently infected.

snippet.textDisplay:
Can we just play this, on every channel, at least once an hour? Please. So elegantly put and it will really help people understand why decisions are being made in what seems to be rapid succession, but in reality, it is likely in a slow response. There are people who get it - the topic you have covered here - and there are those that do not. There is this weird, unexplainable resistance to stopping this pandemic that I would have never imagined. It's pretty infuriating. It seems as if a large portion of people is more concerned about their own comfort - or discomfort - then the good of everyone.

If we would all heed the warnings, stay home, wash our hands, and take a moment to stop posting about how fake everything is or how bad various leaders are responding to this global crisis, it would be over in a matter of weeks or a few months. The longer people screw around, the longer it is going to take to resolve.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi! We are a team of young people that creates awareness videos on different social issues in Nepal. The COVID-19 pandemic is finally approaching Nepal and there is a lot of misinformation regarding the same. We found this video really informative. However, a large section of the population here does not understand English and we would like to use certain clips from this video to create an awareness video in the Nepali language.
We have done a similar exercise before, of translation videos in English into Nepali, as you can see from the videos we have uploaded.
Please let us know if we can go ahead with this or if there are any further requirements? We look forward to your response.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hi! We are a team of young people that creates awareness videos on different social issues in Nepal. The COVID-19 pandemic is finally approaching Nepal and there is a lot of misinformation regarding the same. We found this video really informative. However, a large section of the population here does not understand English and we would like to use certain clips from this video to create an awareness video in the Nepali language.  
We have done a similar exercise before, of translation videos in English into Nepali, as you can see from the videos we have uploaded.
Please let us know if we can go ahead with this or if there are any further requirements? We look forward to your response.

snippet.textDisplay:
The first lesson is to avoid over-confidence about scientific insights. Major flu pandemics arise on average only about three times every century, which means scientists can make relatively few direct observations in each lifetime and have a long time to think about each observation. That is a circumstance ripe for over-interpretation.


https://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/87/6/09-040609/en/?fbclid=IwAR2lB3xg_MWCKAzYpKjN8PVIN1HvNl148rW7Oc8Xio5HdZRMLQMP5FNi_PE
snippet.textOriginal:

Major flu pandemics arise on average only about three times every century, which means scientists can make relatively few direct observations in each lifetime and have a long time to think about each observation. That is a circumstance ripe for over-interpretation.

snippet.textDisplay:
Yea, this is a really good video. Initially, I thought the media was over-reacting, mainly because they do that for everything else. Fortunately, there are enough better sources of information. I think the closing of schools and larger gatherings are both good ideas. People who can work from home is fine too.
I'm living in a state (CA), that's on 'lockdown'. I think they (the Governer) need to be a little clearer on the time from. If the full lockdown last more than 2 weeks, the economic turmoil 'might' be worse than the virus.
As it is, a fair amount of people are still driving around(which is safer than walking). A fair amount of people work in the 'essential businesses'. It's actually a pretty large list. Plenty of places to buy food and supplies are still open.
I would hope that after 3 weeks, they can get back to normal, outside of the large gatherings.
Like the video said, they're not trying to completely contain the virus, just level out the spread. I would think a few weeks of containment would do that, but noone is being too clear with that information.
snippet.textOriginal:
Yea, this is a really good video. Initially, I thought the media was over-reacting, mainly because they do that for everything else. Fortunately, there are enough better sources of information. I think the closing of schools and larger gatherings are both good ideas. People who can work from home is fine too. 
I'm living in a state (CA), that's on 'lockdown'. I think they (the Governer) need to be a little clearer on the time from. If the full lockdown last more than 2 weeks, the economic turmoil 'might' be worse than the virus.
As it is, a fair amount of people are still driving around(which is safer than walking). A fair amount of people work in the 'essential businesses'. It's actually a pretty large list. Plenty of places to buy food and supplies are still open. 
I would hope that after 3 weeks, they can get back to normal, outside of the large gatherings. 
Like the video said, they're not trying to completely contain the virus, just level out the spread. I would think a few weeks of containment would do that, but noone is being too clear with that information.

snippet.textDisplay:
If your singular focus is creating the best-case scenario for this pandemic, then this solution is perfectly acceptable and not an overreaction. Scientific theory tends to work amazingly well in a vacuum. The problem is that there are more considerations than just the pandemic, and in the real world there are consequences beyond improving the survivability rate. There is very little talk here of actual statistical benefit, and there is no mention of COST. We will be entering a depression due to these actions and that will carry with it a major human cost. Lest you think that there are no consequences to economics, just bear in mind that 9.1 million people in the world starve to death every year.


The Spanish Flu chart at 7:15 is confusing, why show the death rate per 100k people when it would seem to be more important to know the total amount of deaths in the two cities per 100k people? I've read that the death rate in St Louis was half of what the death rate in Philadelphia was, but if the duration was twice as long the net outcome would be the same. Would love some clarification on what the weighted death toll was between the two cities, but at the end of the day the coronavirus, which affects predominately the sick and elderly (with a MAYBE 1% mortality rate) is much different than the Spanish flu which afflicted the young and healthy and had a staggering estimated 10% mortality rate.
